newsitem.title: SRI LANKA: S.Lanka to divest holding in three estate firms.
newsitem.headline: S.Lanka to divest holding in three estate firms.

text.p: Sri Lanka will begin selling government holdings in three plantations on the stock exchange on Friday as part of the second phase of its privatisation programme, a senior official said on Monday.

"Fifty-one percent or 10.2 million shares in Maturata Plantations Ltd will be sold on the stock exchange on Friday at a minimum price of 30 rupees a share," said an official of the Public Enterprise Reform Commission (PERC), who declined to be identified.

The three pre-qualified bidders to take part in the sale are Employees Trust Fund (ETF), a state managed gratuity fund; Crop Management Services Ltd, a unit of Chemical Industries and Wayamba Plantations Lanka (Pvt) Ltd, the official said.

PERC, the state arm which oversees privatisations, said 51 percent or 10.2 million shares in Namunukula Plantations and Malwatte Plantations, will also be sold on the stock exchange on June 2 and 4, respectively, at a minimum price of 30 rupees a share.

Those pre-qualified to bid for Namunukula are Forbes Ceylon Ltd ; Plantation Investment Management Co (PIMC), a joint venture between Merchant Bank, ETF and the state-owned Insurance Corporation and Keells Plantation Management Services, a subsidiary of John Keells Holdings.
The pre-qualified bidders for Malwatte are Keells Plantation Management Services and PIMC.
Sri Lanka began privatising management of its 23 regional estate firms, which own some 600,000 hectares of tea, rubber and coconut lands, in 1992.

The privatisation of ownership began in 1995 by selling 51 percent to a strategic investor and 20 percent to the public. Ten percent was reserved for the employees while the state retained the remaining 19 percent.

The process has been completed in the case of six plantation firms, which are now trading on the Colombo Stock Exchnage. They are Kegalle Plantations Ltd, Kotagala Plantations Ltd, Kelani Valley Plantations Ltd, Bogawantala Plantations Ltd, Agalawatte Plantations Ltd and Horana Plantations.
The government recently sold off its 19 percent holding in the six listed firms, retaining one 'golden share', which enables it to intervene in the event of mismanagement.
